items.content:
Together withÂ 

#â€‹565 â€” October 26, 2022 | Read on the web

Image via: Evil Martians

OKLCH in CSS â€” The new CSS Color Module 4 adds many fresh ways to declare color in CSS, including oklch() â€”Â this post dives into why itâ€™s the most interesting, how it works, and why you may want to adopt it over RGB andÂ HSL.

Andry Sitnik & Travis Turner

Let's Talk About Web Components â€” Brad looks at how web components can help deliver design system component libraries and their compatibility with JS libraries and frameworks. Noting that â€œweb components are part of the webâ€. That they are good for the web, and that â€œwe should be rooting forÂ themâ€.

Brad Frost

React Authentication, Simplified â€” In this article, we lay out a new approach to authentication (plus access control & SSO) in ReactÂ applications.

Userfront sponsor

Why We Need CSS Speech â€” The CSS Speech Module (currently a candidate recommendation) is a set of CSS properties intended to let authors design the aural presentation of content. LÃ©onie notes how currently the spec is too big, and needs slimming down so it can moveÂ forward.

LÃ©onie Watson

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The proposed 'Element Capture' API will allow a site to capture an HTML element as a video stream.

  • Here's a handy roundup of recent developments in the browser devtool space across Firefox, Chrome, Safari, and Edge.

  • The CSS Working Group has published two First Public Working Drafts, one defining the View Transition API, and another for scroll-linked animations.

  • Google is ending support for future Chrome updates on Windows 7 / 8.1 early next year.

  • Mozilla "deserves our love" for implementing a better PDF reader in the new Firefox 106.

  • ğŸ‚ Happy 21st birthday to the ever valuable Wayback Machine â€” launched in October 2001.

  • If you're looking for some inspiration, this site brings together the 'best' dark mode implementations from across the internet.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

WebKit Features in Safari 16.1 â€” Safari 16 is now available on both macOS Ventura and iPadOS 16. This post digs into the new features this version brings, including Web Push notifications, passkeys, support for animated AVIF images, scroll to text fragment (that's the ability to specify a text snippet in the URL fragment), and plenty of nice CSSÂ fixes.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

Building a Better Web - A Faster YouTube on the Web â€” Hereâ€™s a case study looking over the changes the YouTube Web team has made to improve performance and increase Core Web Vitals pass rates at the videoÂ giant.

Addy Osmani & Sriram Krishnan (Google)

CSS Animated Grid Layouts â€” Chrome 107 joins other browsers in now supporting interpolation of grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows. As explained here, this allows for smooth transitions between states (instead of snapping at the halfway point of anÂ animation).

Bramus

Futuristic CSS â€” Takes a look at some far-fetched and futuristic CSS features that might one day make their way to theÂ browser.

Sacha Greif

Highly Customizable Background Gradients â€” How to create a complex but highly customizable background gradients that can be modified easily using CSS customÂ properties.

Scott Vandehey

Do You Really Understand CSS radial-gradients? â€” A fairly comprehensive dive into how radial gradients function, with plenty of detail that will no doubt help you improve your understanding of themÂ too.

Patrick Brosset

SpeakingÂ up ForÂ Sass â€” In this post from last year the author concedes that although it may not be the â€˜coolestâ€™ thing right now, Sass/SCSS isÂ still an invaluable part of webÂ development. (This post has resurfaced again recently due to this Hacker NewsÂ thread.)

Bryce Wray

Twitter Reminds Us About Alt Text, But How Good Are We AtÂ It? â€” Humble observations on how people describe photos, artworks, andÂ memes.

Slava Shestopalov

Shortcut Brings Product and Engineering Together. Try It forÂ Free

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

What is Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)?
Jakub PomykaÅ‚a

How to Use storage in Web Extensions
David Walsh

Is There Too Much CSS Now?
Sacha Greif

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

a17t: A Tailwind CSS Plugin to Build UIs with Atomic Components â€” This works as a kind of step up from Tailwind. You donâ€™t have to build from nothing, but the components arenâ€™t too opinionated, providing a fairly neutral design language to workÂ with.

Miles McCain

DevTools-X: A Cross-Platform Collection of Offline-First Developer Utilities â€” A collection of tools similar to those native to Mac/Windows. Includes utilities for color, images, JSON, Regex, SQL, and even a live ReactÂ playground.

fosslife

Matrix: A Web Implementation of the 'Raining Green Code' from the Matrix Movies â€” See it in action here. This has been around for a while but it recently was mentioned in Vice Motherboard, and commented on by one of the creators of the filmÂ franchise.

Rezmason

Send Email, Push and SMS with Smart Routing, with Just 8 Lines of Code â€” Send notifications from right within your application using the Courier API. One call, that's all, and send any template to anyÂ channel.

Courier.com sponsor

Satori: Convert HTML and CSS to SVG â€” A new â€˜enlightenedâ€™ library from Vercel. Supports the JSXÂ syntax.

Vercel

98.css: CSS for Building Faithful Recreations of Windows 98 â€” We last linked this three years ago, but itâ€™s doing the rounds again. If for any reason you need your siteâ€™s interface to look like Windows first did 24 years ago.. ğŸ˜†

Jordan Scales

Software Engineer â€” Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.

items.content:
Together withÂ 

#â€‹564 â€” October 19, 2022 | Read on the web

Creating a World-Class Code Playground with Sandpack â€” A couple of months ago we featured the release of CodeSandboxâ€™s Sandpack, a toolkit for creating your own â€˜live code editorâ€™ components. Josh Comeau shows off how to actually use it to good effect to boost your blog posts, documentation, etc.

Josh W Comeau

â–¶Â Â The State of CSS Frameworks â€” An hour-long discussion with â€œknowledge leaders, library and methodology authors, and CSS aficionadosâ€ about the recent features added to CSS and what libraries and trends you should investigate for yourÂ projects. (1 hour 3 minutes.)

This Dot Media

Discover New HTML Elements & CSS Selectors â€” Join Jen Kramer for this detailed video course on intermediate HTML and CSS techniques, covering semantic HTML, inheritance, specificity, the cascade, and more. You'll also get a hands-on look at using new selectors such as :has(), :is(), andÂ :where().

Frontend Masters sponsor

Creating Halftone Patterns with CSS â€” Looks at how to recreate a dotted, halftone style image effect using vanillaÂ CSS, including the radial-gradient() background-image property. Quite a cute approach.

Michelle Barker

A First Look at the 'Websites and Software Applications Accessibility Act Bill' â€” The U.S. Congress recently introduced a new bill to ensure digital accessibility for websites and applications. Here, Ben takes aÂ look.

Ben Myers

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • In an effort to get up to speed on modern CSS techniques Manuel Matuzovic is sharing 100 days of CSS tidbits. He's currently on day 18 so there's already much to enjoy, both cutting edge and some slightly less so.

  • Firefox Nightly updates are on pause due to a bug with searching via the address bar.

  • Google is bringing passkey support to both Android and Chrome.

  • Chrome 108+ has experimental support for CSS 'toggles', meaning you can implement carousel and tab components with CSS.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

When Life Gives You Lemons, Write Better Error Messages â€” So, what makes a good error message? The Wix team attempts to offer clarity on that â€” theyâ€™ve recently edited thousands of error message prompts to ensure they are all inclusive, helpful, and aid the overall userÂ experience.

Jenni Nadler

From Development to Real Users: How to Create a Web Performance Story â€” An engineer at Spotify shares how having good tooling in place can help you measure, monitor, and identify key moments in a userâ€™s journey, and take appropriate action for impactful results.

Vinicius Teixeira Dallacqua (Spotify)

Marketing Notifications Suck and Everyone Toggles ThemÂ Off â€” Make sure important and transactional notifications get delivered with Courier. Get aÂ Demo.

Courier.com sponsor

Using Web Components with Next.js (or any SSR Framework) â€” A current shortcoming of web components is that they lack support for server-side rendering. This means that, in JavaScript frameworks, the code to make Web Components work doesnâ€™t run until hydration occurs. This post looks at a potential solution to this (with some significantÂ caveats).

Adam Rackis

"Why We're Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS" â€” A software engineer shares what originally attracted them to the idea of keeping CSS and JS together, and why they (along with the rest of their team) have decided to shift away fromÂ it.

Sam Magura

The Wasted Potential of CSS Attribute Selectors â€” A long-time BEM user muses on treating attribute selectors on par with classes â€œas first-classÂ citizensâ€.

Elise Hein

â–¶Â Â Let's Implement Tic Tac Toe with React, HTML and CSS â€” For those newer to React a simple, clear application objective implemented from start to finish. (21Â minutes.)

Chris Power

â–¶Â Â Behind the Source: jQuery with Tomasz Åakomy â€” In this podcast Tomasz Åakomy and Mike Street discuss jQuery - asking if it is still relevant today, and whether it is really â€œso badâ€? ~30Â minutes.

Mike Street podcast

How to Animate CSS Box Shadows and Optimize Performance
Oscar Jite-Orimiono

Dark Mode UI Design Best Practices
OndÅ™ej PeÅ¡iÄka

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Introduction to WebC for Single File Web Components â€” A new single file web components tool by Zach Leatherman (creator of popular SSG Eleventy) for serializing custom elements at build time. It aggregates component-level CSS and JS, allowing devs to keep their styles/scripts together with the markup as single file components (the way you may be used to if you work with frameworks such as Svelte orÂ Vue). â–¶ï¸ Here's a quick crash course video on how to use it.

W. Evan Sheehan

whyframe: Develop Components in Isolation InsideÂ iframes â€” This could be useful if youâ€™re building some kind of documentation that needs to demonstrate interactive components in an isolated example on theÂ page.

Bjorn Lu
